School of Environment and Energy, South China University of Technology Guangzhou 510006 China 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. The supported catalyst of Pt-CeO2/BEA with low loading amount (0.07 wt%) of Pt nanoparticles presented competitive performance towards catalytic ozonation of toluene. Characterization results demonstrated that the improved activity could be attributed to the enhanced Pt-CeO2 strong metal-support interaction induced by the formation of much smaller, more uniform and dispersive Pt nanoparticles through the adsorption method. Furthermore, Pt/CeO2 and Pt/SiO2 were employed to elucidate the intrinsic reasons for the activity improvement. Various techniques such as XPS, Raman, O2-TPD, etc. were performed to characterize the physicochemical properties. Results showed that the anchoring effect for Pt nanoparticles by the Pt-O-Ce bonds, greater amount of oxygen vacancies and more generated peroxide species are potentially responsible for the improvement of catalytic performance. In-situ Raman confirmed the participation of peroxide species in toluene oxidation, which were previously formed during the ozone decomposition. Plausible reaction pathways for the involving reactions on catalyst surface were also proposed. Graphical Abstract In-situ Raman spectroscopy confirmed the participation of O2 2- in ozone-catalytic oxidation of toluene on Pt-CeO2/BEA catalysts prepared by adsorption method. ga1 Keywords Catalytic ozonation Pt-CeO2 catalysts Particle adsorption method Peroxide species In-situ Raman 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are an important pollutant that can seriously affect the quality of the atmospheric environment and are directly harmful to humans by causing short- and long-term adverse health effects [1]. In recent years, VOCs control technologies such as adsorption, catalytic combustion, non-thermal plasma degradation, etc. are widely investigated [2]. Among them, catalytic ozonation of VOCs, also named ozone-catalytic oxidation of VOCs that can effectively and simultaneously decompose VOCs and O3 to the harmless CO2, H2O and O2 under mild and environmentally friendly conditions, has long been the subject of intense studies [3]. This method can be applied not only for the treatment of industrial organic waste gas but also for indoor air purification, representing a potential VOCs control technology [4,5]. At present, the most common catalysts for the catalytic ozonation of VOCs are transition metal-based catalysts, such as MnOx, FeOx, CoOx, etc., which are generally dispersed on support with high surface area (activated carbon, zeolite, γ-Al2O3, etc.) to increase the number of active sites and improve the gas-solid interactions [6]. Based on the literature [6–8], many catalysts display a moderate catalytic activity. However, the low mineralization rate, undesired by-product formation and O3 residues significantly hinder their practical application [9,10]. Zhu et al. [11] have conducted catalytic ozonation of benzene on AgMn/HZSM-5 catalysts at room temperature. The results showed that the CO2 selectivity was lower than 60% even though benzene and O3 achieved the highest conversion. Similar results have also been observed by other authors [12–15]. Hui et al. [15] have prepared a series of MCM-41 catalysts modified by different transition metal oxides (Co and Cu) for catalytic ozonation of toluene. At 22 ℃, the CO2 selectivity reached only 40% in the Co-modified MCM-41, which, however, represented the best activity. Therefore, it is still of great necessity to develop novel catalysts with enhanced performance. Due to the high oxygen storage capacity and the possibility of readily switching ability between Ce3+ and Ce4+, together with rich oxygen vacancy concentration, CeO2 exhibits special catalytic properties [16]. Many researches demonstrate the relatively high O3 conversion and CO2 selectivity for the catalytic ozonation of VOCs by using the CeO2. Zhang et al. [17] have degraded formaldehyde and O3 over CeO2 and the results showed that the CO2 yield could achieve 97% with an O3 conversion of approximately 90% at room temperature. The high performance of CeO2 is associated with its surface oxygen vacancies, which are favorable for O3 adsorption and decomposition to provide active oxygen species (AOS). As a reducible material, CeO2 can forcefully bind the highly dispersed metal particles with oxygen linkages and generate active sites through the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI), involving electron transfer and formation of metal-O-Ce bonds on the interface of metal and CeO2 [18]. Pt nanoparticles (NPs) are promising catalytically active components and are generally combined with CeO2 to improve catalytic activity and stability [19]. Various preparation methods have been applied to prepare the Pt-CeO2 catalyst by tuning the SMSI between Pt NPs and CeO2. Among them, Pt NPs adsorption method is intensively reported owing to the operability, repeatability and controllability of particle size and loading amount. He et al. [20] and Sun et al. [21] have prepared supported noble metal catalysts of Pt-Mn/SiO2 and Pd/Ce-SBA15, respectively, through the adsorption method. The results have demonstrated an improved catalytic activity due to the SMSI. Nevertheless, the loading amount of noble metal NPs for supported catalysts in the literature is usually approximately 1 wt% or more, which breaches the cost-effectiveness and restricts their industrial application [22]. Reducing the amount of precious metals while maintaining or even enhancing the catalytic performance is still a great challenge for scientific research. In the present study, a cost-effective Pt-CeO2/BEA catalyst was prepared by the Pt NPs adsorption method with a Pt loading amount lower in order of magnitude than those reported in the literature. The sample showed encouraging performance on the catalytic ozonation of toluene with a remarkably increased CO2 selectivity. Furthermore, Pt/CeO2 and Pt/SiO2 were also synthesized to elucidate the promotion effect of the Pt-CeO2 SMSI. Various characterization techniques such as XRD, HRTEM, H2-TPR, O2-TPD, XPS, in-situ Raman, etc. were used to investigate the formation of the Pt-O-Ce bonds, variation of oxygen vacancy concentration and the type and role of AOS. The goal of this work is to develop highly efficient supported catalysts by lowering the loading amount of precious metal while enhancing the catalytic performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Preparation of Pt NPs All the involved chemicals are analytical grade without any further purification. Pt NPs were synthesized by the glycol reduction method, as described elsewhere [23]. Briefly, 2.5 mL H2PtCl6 solution (20 g/L) and 220 mg PVP (k29-32, Mw=58000) were dissolved in 25 mL glycol in a round-bottom flask, and a yellow solution was obtained. Under mild stirring, the yellow solution was heated to 120 ℃ for 1 h, until the color changed to dark-brown. Then, 60 mL acetone was slowly added to the dark-brown solution to extract Pt NPs. After cooling down to room temperature, Pt NPs were collected by centrifugation and washed with n-hexane several times. Finally, the obtained Pt NPs were dispersed into ethanol for subsequent utilization. 2.1.2 Preparation of Pt-CeO2/BEA CeO2/BEA was prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method with β-zeolite (BEA) as support. Typically, a certain amount of Ce(NO3)3.6H2O was dissolved in deionized water. After stirring for 10 min, a corresponding quantity of BEA, which was pre-calcined to remove the adsorbed water, was added to the above solution to achieve a loading amount of about 1.5 wt% for the Ce. The obtained mixed slurry was then treated by ultrasonic for 1 h with a frequency of 60 kHz. Afterward, the slurry was dried at 110 ℃ overnight and calcined at 550 ℃ for 5 h with a heating rate of 1 ℃/min. Pt-CeO2/BEA catalyst was prepared by the Pt NPs adsorption method, denoted as Pt-CeO 2 /BEA-P. The preparation and loading process of Pt NPs was identical to that described previously, i.e., adding a certain amount of CeO2/BEA into the Pt NPs solution under ultrasonic treatment for 1 h. After drying at 80 ℃ overnight and calcining at 550 ℃ for 5 h, the Pt-CeO2/BEA-P catalyst was obtained. Meanwhile, another Pt-CeO2/BEA catalyst was synthesized via the incipient wetness impregnation method for comparison, denoted as Pt-CeO 2 /BEA-IM. A certain amount of CeO2/BEA was added to the H2PtCl6 solution under ultrasonic treatment. After drying overnight, the solid product was calcined at 550 ℃ for 5 h. 2.1.3 Preparation of Pt/CeO2 and Pt/SiO2 CeO2 was obtained from Ce(NO3)3.6 H2O by calcined in the muffle furnace at 550 ℃ for 5 h. Commercial SiO2 (Fuchen Chemical Reagent Factory, Tianjin, China) was selected as the contrast support. Both Pt/CeO 2 and Pt/SiO 2 were synthesized through the Pt NPs adsorption method. To better elucidating the Pt-CeO2 SMSI, the loading amount of Pt NPs was moderately increased to approximately 0.4 wt%. Typically, a certain amount of CeO2 or SiO2 was added to the Pt NPs solution. After ultrasonic treatment for 1 h, the mixed slurry was dried at 80 ℃ overnight and finally calcined at 350 ℃ for 5 h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Physicochemical properties of the catalysts were analyzed through various techniques, such as XRD, N2 adsorption/desorption, SEM, HRTEM, XPS, H2-TPR, O2-TPD, etc. Detailed experimental procedures can be seen in Supporting Information (SI). 2.3 In-situ Raman spectroscopy Because of the covalency of the O-O bond in superoxide (O2 -) and peroxide species (O2 2-), their stretching vibration has a high response in the visible Raman spectra, which were thus employed to characterize these two important AOS. In this case, the wavelength of the excitation light source was 532 nm and the scanning range was 700–1400 cm-1. The in-situ Raman experiment process was designed as shown in Fig. S1. To remove adsorbed water from the surface, all the samples were pretreated at 150 ℃ for 1 h under N2 flow. (1) Recording the initial Raman signals of the sample in N2 atmosphere after cooling to 30 ℃; (2) switching the gas to 21% O2/N2 for O2 adsorption and recording the signals after blowing for 30 min; (3) switching the gas to 4900 ppm O3/(O2 +N2) and recording the signals after reaction for 30 min; (4) switching the gas to N2 to remove the weakly adsorbed surface oxygen species and recording the signals after blowing for 30 min; (5) switching the gas to 940 ppm toluene/N2 and recording the signals after reaction for 30 min 2.4 Catalytic performance evaluation 25 mg catalyst (40–60 mesh) was placed into a quartz tube (8 mm inner diameter and 500 mm length) with quartz wool packed at both ends of the catalyst bed. Before each experiment, the catalyst was purged with N2 at 120 ℃ for 30 min to remove the adsorbed water molecules. After cooling to room temperature, a gas mixture of (O3 and N2) or (toluene, O3 and N2) passed through the reactor while increasing the temperature. The concentrations of toluene, CO and CO2 were analyzed by an online gas chromatograph (GC-9560, China) equipped with two flame ionization detectors (FID); O3 concentration was recorded by an O3 analyzer (2B, 106-M, USA). O3 decomposition ( X O 3 ), toluene conversion ( X Toluene ), CO2 selectivity ( S CO 2 ), carbon balance ( B carbon ) and CO2 yield ( Y CO 2 ) were calculated according to the equations listed in SI. Besides, experiments of thermal catalytic oxidation of toluene (denoted as catalyst-T) were also carried out. Experimental conditions were the same as those for the catalytic ozonation of toluene, with the only difference of the absence of O3 in the inlet gas mixture. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 BEA supported catalysts 3.1.1 Catalytic performance evaluation Catalytic performance for the Pt-CeO2/BEA-IM and Pt-CeO2/BEA-P with Pt loading amount of approximately 0.06 wt% was evaluated, as shown in Fig. 1. Toluene conversion, CO2 selectivity, carbon balance and O3 conversion increased with temperature for both catalysts. Pt-CeO2/BEA-P presented better catalytic performance with a CO2 selectivity and O3 conversion reaching 100% at 90 ℃ and 70 ℃, respectively, while those for Pt-CeO2/BEA-IM were only 75% and 87% at the corresponding temperature. In addition, the CO2 selectivity of CeO2/BEA and Pt-CeO2/BEA-IM showed a downward trend after 70 ℃, which could be possibly ascribed to the accumulation of by-products on these catalysts. In fact, in order to obtain the selectivity data of each temperature, the holding time of the test was long (> 2 h). Since the CO2 selectivity was not 100%, it may lead to the accumulation of organic by-products. This phenomenon further highlighted the outstanding catalytic activity of the Pt-CeO2/BEA-P, which displayed special performance for the CO2 selectivity due to the ability for the decomposition of by-products. Carbon balance for Pt-CeO2/BEA-P was also higher, especially at lower temperatures. As evidenced in Fig. 2, the better catalytic performance could be primarily due to the higher O3 conversion in the absence of toluene [14]. Moreover, the BEA support could display a certain O3 decomposition ability owing to the presence of acid sites with Al element [24], which further contributed to the catalytic activity. Although the actual Pt loading amount of Pt-CeO2/BEA-P is much lower than that in our previous study [25], its catalytic performance is fairly encouraging and comparable to those reported in the literature, as summarized in Table S1. The competitive results could be possibly attributed to the enhanced SMSI between Pt NPs and CeO2 induced by the Pt NPs adsorption method [20,21]. The enhanced SMSI creates a higher amount of oxygen vacancies and thus provides more active sites for O3 adsorption and decomposition [26]. During this process, electrons from the O atoms are transferred to Ce ions by reducing the Ce4+ to Ce3+. Oxygen vacancies are then generated, acting as active sites to decompose the adsorbed O3 into AOS. Subsequently, the highly reactive AOS can oxidize the adsorbed toluene into intermediate products and finally to CO2 when toluene is present in the gaseous phase [27]. Moreover, consecutive runs under different relative humidity (RH) and long-term catalytic performance of toluene oxidation over the best performing catalyst Pt-CeO2/BEA-P were conducted to investigate the stability of the catalyst. It could be found in Fig. 1(e) that toluene conversion still remained above 99% under 30% and 50% RH. When the RH increased to 97%, water vapor exhibited a negative effect on the catalytic activity. As seen in Fig. 1(f), no significant decrease in toluene conversion was observed during 12 h test under dry air. Even though under extreme conditions such as 97% RH, the catalyst could still show a relatively stable performance. These results demonstrate the good reaction stability of the catalyst. 3.1.2 Catalyst characterization Specific surface area (SSA), pore diameter and volume of the catalysts were determined by N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms, as presented in Table 1 and Fig. S2. Compared with pure BEA, SSA for the supported catalysts decreased to about 555 m2/g and the difference between each other is negligible. This proves the successful loading of Pt NPs and CeO2 on the BEA. For the pore diameter distribution, the influence of Pt NPs and CeO2 on the structure of BEA could be ignored, mainly due to their low loading amount, high dispersion and large SSA of the BEA. These results were further testified by XRD (Fig. S3), in which peaks related to the Pt and Ce species are not observed and the crystal structure of BEA could be well preserved after the loading of Pt NPs and CeO2. The morphology of the catalysts was analyzed by TEM and HRTEM. As seen from Fig. 3, Pt NPs with different sizes ranging from 4 to 30 nm are dispersed on the surface of Pt-CeO2/BEA-IM. Whereas, Pt NPs are relatively uniform in shape with an average size of about 5 nm and well distributed on the Pt-CeO2/BEA-P. From HRTEM images in Fig. 3(b) and (e), lattice fringes of 0.23 and 0.31 nm can be observed, corresponding to the (111) crystal facets of Pt and CeO2, respectively. It should be pointed out that Pt NPs seem to randomly distribute on the surface of Pt-CeO2/BEA-IM; however, they are selectively dispersed around CeO2 in the Pt-CeO2/BEA-P, which can increase the contact possibility between each other. From these observations, one can conclude that the size of Pt NPs and the presence of contact interface between Pt NPs and CeO2 are closely related to the preparation method. Compared with the traditional impregnation method, Pt NPs are much smaller, more uniform and dispersive through the adsorption method. Zhang et al. [21] have synthesized Pd/Ce-SBA15 catalysts using the electrostatic adsorption method and impregnation method. The authors found that Pd NPs were highly deposited around CeO2 in the sample prepared by the electrostatic adsorption method, which exhibited enhanced SMSI and better catalytic activity. He et al. [20] have prepared Pt-Mn/SiO2 catalyst by the Pt NPs adsorption method. Characterization results showed that Pt NPs closely contacted with Mn2O3 (222) crystal facets and interacted with them to form Pt-O-Mn bonds, which facilitated the electron transfer from Mn to Pt, ultimately increased the proportion of Pt0/Pt2+ on the surface and then improved the catalyst activity and stability. Therefore, the close contact between Pt NPs and CeO2 is proved to enhance the Pt-CeO2 SMSI, which could significantly affect the catalytic performance. The information on surface coordination and oxidation state of CeO2 was studied by UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy and the results are shown in Fig. 4(a). In the spectra, absorption peaks at about 250 and 290 nm are attributed to the electron transfer of Ce3+ ← O2- and Ce4+ ← O2-, respectively [28]. Among them, the peak intensity at 250 nm is the strongest for Pt-CeO2/BEA-P, followed by Pt-CeO2/BEA-IM and CeO2/BEA, signifying that the loading of Pt NPs can effectively increase the Ce3+ proportion and thus the Pt-CeO2/BEA-P possesses the largest amount of Ce3+. This may be ascribed to the greater contact possibility and the larger interface between Pt NPs and CeO2, resulting in more conducive for the electron transfer and hence an enhanced SMSI. A higher Ce3+ proportion usually means more oxygen vacancies that facilitate the O3 decomposition [19]. Besides, toluene-TPD was used to determine the toluene adsorption capacity for the catalysts. As exhibited in Fig. 4(b), a toluene desorption peak appears in the temperature range of 50–230 ℃ for all the samples. The temperatures of toluene desorption for Pt-CeO2/BEA-IM and CeO2/BEA are rather closed, which are 134.1 ℃ and 136.2 ℃, respectively, while that for Pt-CeO2/BEA-P is much higher (147.5 ℃). This result indicates that toluene has the strongest binding force with the surface of Pt-CeO2/BEA-P, which benefits the adsorption of toluene and therefore facilitates the degradation. It should be pointed out that due to such low loading amount of Pt NPs and CeO2 on the BEA, little information about the chemical states, oxygen vacancies and AOS was obtained by XPS, H2-TPR and O2-TPD analysis, etc., as shown in Fig. S5 and Fig. S6. To further elucidate the intrinsic reasons for the performance improvement related to the Pt-CeO2 SMSI, Pt/CeO2 sample without BEA, also prepared by the Pt NPs adsorption method, was employed for subsequent investigation and compared with Pt/SiO2 that is characterized by the inert support. 3.2 Catalysts of Pt/CeO2 and Pt/SiO2 3.2.1 Catalytic performance evaluation Fig. 5 depicts the results of catalytic ozonation of toluene for Pt/CeO2 and Pt/SiO2. To exclude the effect of thermal catalysis, experiments of thermal catalytic oxidation of toluene by CeO2 and Pt/CeO2 were also carried out, corresponding to the curves of CeO2-T and Pt/CeO2-T in Fig. 5(a), respectively. When O3 was absent in the inlet, the maximum toluene conversion for CeO2-T and Pt/CeO2-T was only 1% and 2%, respectively, indicating that the effect of thermal catalysis could be ignored within the temperature range of 30–110 ℃. After introducing the O3, toluene conversion significantly increased for both samples, and that of Pt/CeO2 was much superior. At 80 ℃, toluene conversion, CO2 yield and O3 conversion of Pt/CeO2 were 92.3%, 92.1% and 99.9%, respectively. This result confirms the promotion effect of Pt NPs and the pivotal role of O3 in the enhancement of toluene oxidation. O3 decomposition ability in the absence of toluene was also tested (Fig. 5(d)). Pt/CeO2 presented a higher O3 decomposition ability with a stable O3 conversion of approximate 90% during the test of 150 min at 30 ℃, while that of CeO2 decreased to 80%. This result is in accordance with the catalytic activity for toluene oxidation. To clarify whether the improvement effect is attributed to the Pt NPs alone or the interaction between Pt NPs and CeO2, the influence of the support was evaluated with Pt/SiO2, of which SiO2 is well-known as an inert support. Since toluene and O3 conversions were lower than 5% for SiO2 whatever the temperature was, the catalytic activity displayed by Pt/SiO2 could be roughly regarded to that of Pt NPs. At 110 ℃, toluene and O3 conversions for Pt/SiO2 were 10.2% and 43.3%, respectively, confirming the effect of Pt NPs for the reaction. When a comparison is carried out between Pt/SiO2 and Pt/CeO2, the catalytic performance of the latter is much better. For the performance improvement in Pt/CeO2, individual Pt NPs play a role rather limited, while the interaction, specifically, the Pt-CeO2 SMSI is predominant. Concretely, the enhanced Pt-CeO2 SMSI induced by the Pt NPs adsorption method can increase the concentration of oxygen vacancies in CeO2, which are favorable for O3 adsorption and decomposition, giving rise to the improvement of toluene oxidation [19]. The better catalytic performance of Pt/CeO2 could be also attributed to the anchoring effect for Pt NPs through the formation of Pt-O-Ce bonds, in which electronic interaction between Ce4+, O2- and Pt2+ facilitates the redox exchanges through electron transfer via Pt2+-O2--Ce4+-Pt2+ linkage [29,30]: Ce4+-O2--Pt2+ + e ↔ Ce4+-O2--Pt+ ↔ Ce3+-O2--Pt2+ ↔ Ce4+-O2--Pt2+ + e In any case, such electron transfer is inexistent in Pt/SiO2. To sum up, the performance improvement in Pt/CeO2 is mainly attributed to the accessibility of the Ce4+/Ce3+ redox couple with Pt2+/Pt0 through the oxygen vacancies, resulting in lowering the reaction temperature. A more detailed explanation of the improvement effect by Pt-CeO2 SMSI will be discussed in the following sections. 3.2.2 Catalyst characterization 3.2.2.1 Structural and morphological properties XRD was employed to evaluate the nature of the crystalline phases. From Fig. 6(a), characteristic peaks of the face-centered cubic fluorite structure of ceria (PDF 34-0394) are observed for both CeO2 and Pt/CeO2, indicating that the crystal structure of CeO2 is not affected by the addition of Pt NPs. No diffraction peaks related to the Pt (40° and 33°, PDF 65-2868) and PtOx species (Pt2O in 40° and 33°, PDF 65-5066; PtO in 30° and 32°, PDF 65-6984) are displayed, which is attributed to the low loading amount, small particle size and high dispersion of Pt NPs on the CeO2 surface. As determined from the diffraction peak (111), the lattice parameter of Pt/CeO2 is slightly smaller than that of pure CeO2 ( Table 2). This decreased value certifies the incorporation of partial Pt2+(rPt2+= 0.074 nm) or Pt4+(rPt4+= 0.076 nm) species into the fluorite-like lattice of CeO2 (rCe4+= 0.094 nm), resulting in the shrinkage of the cell to form a defective structure and also the formation of Pt-O-Ce bonds due to the Pt-CeO2 SMSI [19]. The formation of Pt-O-Ce bonds can suppress the agglomeration of Pt NPs since the highly dispersed Pt oxide on the CeO2 surface under oxidizing conditions is considered to be more stable owing to the greater bond energy of Pt-O-Ce bonds [31]. The SSA and pore diameter are also presented in Table 2 and Fig. 6(b). After loading Pt NPs, the SSA slightly increases from 64.8 to 69.9 m2/g, which may be ascribed to the loading of Pt NPs on the catalyst surface. Besides, the hysteresis loop located at the relative pressure of 0.7–0.9 in adsorption/desorption isotherms signifies the presence of a large mesoporous structure and the preservation of the pore structure in the samples. The morphology of the catalysts and the Pt NPs size distribution are illustrated in Fig. 7. As seen in the images, Pt NPs are uniformly distributed on CeO2 and SiO2 surfaces. In HRTEM images, lattice fringes of 0.21 nm can be observed, which correspond to the (111) crystal facets of Pt NPs. From Fig. 7(c) and (f), the average particle size of Pt NPs is (3.6 ± 0.3) nm and (3.4 ± 0.3) nm for Pt/CeO2 and Pt/SiO2, respectively, indicating that different support has little effect on the particle size distribution through the Pt NPs adsorption method. The mentioned structural and morphological properties testify the low loading amount, uniform particle size and high dispersion of Pt NPs on both Pt/CeO2 and Pt/SiO2. 3.2.2.2 Chemical states XPS was performed to obtain further insight into the composition and chemical states of the surface elements. Fig. 8 presents the XPS spectra of Ce 3d and O 1s for CeO2 and Pt/CeO2. Two valence states mainly exist in CeO2, namely Ce3+ and Ce4+. According to the literature, Ce 3d spectra can be fitted with ten components that take into account the spin-orbit splitting of Ce 3d5/2, Ce 3d3/2 and other splitting caused by the redistribution of the entire energy spectrum [32]. Six peaks corresponding to three pairs of spin-orbit doublets noted as U’’’(916.1 eV), V’’’(897.6 eV), U’’(906.9 eV), V’’(888.5 eV), U(900.3 eV) and V(881.9 eV), are assigned to the characteristic peaks of Ce4+ oxide; while the other four peaks due to two pairs of doublets, noted as U’(901.9 eV), V’(883.9 eV), U0(898.6 eV) and V0(880.6 eV) can be identified as Ce3+ oxide, which is usually served as an indicator for the existence of oxygen vacancy in CeO2 [19]. As summarized in Table 3, the ratio of Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) in CeO2 and Pt/CeO2 is 31.3% and 44.2%, respectively, demonstrating a higher oxygen vacancy concentration in the Pt/CeO2 due to the presence of Pt NPs. Regarding the surface oxygen species, O 1s spectra could be deconvoluted into three characteristic peaks at (528.7–528.9 eV), (530.5–530.7 eV) and (533.5–533.7 eV), which are assigned to the surface lattice oxygen OLat (O2-), surface adsorbed oxygen OSur (O2 2-,O2 -) formed due to the oxygen vacancy and other probably surface adsorbed oxygen species OAds (CO3 2-, -OH), respectively [29,33]. In general, the ratio of OSur/OLat could be used to evaluate the surface oxygen vacancy concentration [30] and the results are presented in Table 3. Pt/CeO2 exhibits a higher amount of surface oxygen vacancy with the OSur/OLat ratio of 86.9% while that for CeO2 is 77.3%, confirming the beneficial effect of Pt NPs for the generation of oxygen vacancies. Notably, on account of the low loading amount of Pt NPs, the detection accuracy for Pt species is precluded by XPS and the Pt 4f spectra are not presented in this study. Partial Pt species could probably get incorporated into the CeO2 matrix due to the highly ionic nature of CeO2 compared to SiO2. Generally, solid solution in form of Ce1−xMxO2−x (M = Pt2+, Pd2+, etc.) is one of the possible approaches for the incorporation of ions in CeO2, since the ionic radii of Pt2+ (80 pm) is close to that of Ce4+ (97 pm). Therefore, O2--Ce4+-O2--Pt2+-O2- type of linkage on CeO2 surface could be formed. The decreased lattice parameter calculated in XRD possibly suggests the ionic substitution of Pt2+ ions for Ce4+ in CeO2. Because of the lower valent ionic substitution, oxygen vacancies are thus created to maintain the charge neutrality. Substitution of Pt2+ in the CeO2 matrix could further enhance the oxygen storage capacity due to the presence of longer bonds [34]. Metiu et al. [34] have demonstrated that substitution of Pt in CeO2 surface weakened the bonds of oxygen atoms in the neighborhood as evidenced by lowering the formation energy of oxygen vacancies, which become much easier to be generated. 3.2.2.3 Oxygen vacancy The structural information of the surface can be obtained by visible Raman spectroscopy, of which the results for CeO2 and Pt/CeO2 are shown in Fig. 9(a). Raman peaks at 258, 460, 598 and 1179 cm-1 are observed for both samples, corresponding to the second-order transverse acoustic mode (2TA), the symmetric stretching vibrations mode (F2 g), the band of defect-induced mode (D) and the second-order longitudinal optical mode (2LO), respectively [35]. The asymmetry of the main peak at 460 cm-1 and the appearance of other weak peaks are caused by the presence of oxygen vacancy defects and lattice strain of CeO2, which facilitate the adsorption, activation and migration of oxygen species [36]. Besides, Pt/CeO2 presents other peaks at 558 and 665 cm-1, belonging to the vibration of Pt-O-Ce and Pt-O bands, respectively [35]. This result directly confirms the formation of Pt-O-Ce bonds in the Pt-CeO2 interface due to the Pt-CeO2 SMSI. Surface oxygen vacancies have been proved to play a key role in catalytic ozonation reactions, which mainly participate in the transformation of AOS on the surface, as well as the adsorption and decomposition of O3 [37]. UV Raman spectroscopy that is sensitive to the defective features was used to detect the surface oxygen vacancies. As depicted in Fig. 9(b), Raman peaks at 417, 459, 592 and 1179 cm-1 are observed for both catalysts. The last three peaks are assigned to the corresponding mode as described in visible Raman spectra; the first peak at 417 cm-1 also appeared in other studies, but its attribution is still unclear [38]. Specifically, the relative intensity ratio of D peak to F2 g peak (ID/IF2g) can be employed to characterize the relative amount of oxygen vacancies in CeO2 [19]. As listed in Table 3, the ID/IF2g value of Pt/CeO2 (0.91) is much greater than that of CeO2 (0.31), meaning a higher oxygen vacancy concentration in the Pt/CeO2. Combined with the XPS results, it can be inferred a positive correlation between the catalytic performance and the amount of oxygen vacancies. 3.2.2.4 Active oxygen species Information about AOS was obtained through H2-TPR and the results are shown in Fig. 10(a). According to the literature, the reduction process of CeO2 could be divided into three temperature ranges of 250–400 ℃, 400–600 ℃ and 600–1000 ℃, attributing to the reduction of surface oxygen, subsurface oxygen and bulk lattice oxygen, respectively [22,39]. Two peaks appearing at 359 ℃ and 458 ℃ in CeO2 represent the reduction of surface and subsurface oxygen, respectively. After loading Pt NPs, three peaks can be observed at 84 ℃, 204 ℃ and 360 ℃, among which the first peak is attributed to the reduction of surface PtOx. Previous studies state that metallic Pt could be oxidized to PtOx by lattice oxygen from CeO2 rather than the O2 in the gaseous phase. As a result, Pt NPs in the Pt/CeO2 act as the oxygen atom acceptor, which decreases the ratio of Ce4+/Ce3+ and thus increases the oxygen vacancy concentration [40]. Besides, the amount of H2 consumption corresponding to this peak is 29.9 μmol/g, which is greater than the theoretical value for the reduction of PtOx (22.1 μmol/g, assuming that Pt species in Pt/CeO2 are Pt4+). This extra oxygen species might come from the surface and/or subsurface of CeO2, resulting in the reduction of Ce4+ adjacent to the Pt species. This phenomenon could be ascribed to the spillover effect induced by the Pt-CeO2 SMSI [31]. Meanwhile, reduction peaks of surface and subsurface oxygen in the Pt/CeO2 shift to a lower temperature (204 ℃ and 360 ℃), suggesting that a small amount of Pt, either Pt2+ or Pt0, can activate the surface Ce-O bonds and promote the surface reduction of CeO2 [41]. This result is probably caused by the relaxation of Ce-O bonds strongly bounded with Pt species. Summarily, the lattice oxygen on the CeO2 surface and/or subsurface could be activated by Pt NPs, leading to an increase of the lattice oxygen mobility and the higher structural defects [19,42]. The type of AOS was analyzed by O2-TPD, which could also reflect information about the oxygen vacancy concentration to some extent based on the amount of desorbed oxygen [43,44]. As depicted in Fig. 10(b), four main desorption peaks are observed in the range of 60–700 ℃ for both samples. Desorption peak at 120 ℃ belongs to the physically adsorbed oxygen O2(ad), other three peaks between 180 and 500 ℃ are assigned to the chemically adsorbed oxygen species such as O2 − (ad) and O− (ad) that adsorb on oxygen vacancies, and the desorption peak for lattice oxygen O2− (lat) is generally located at temperatures higher than 500 ℃ [29]. After loading Pt NPs, the intensity of desorption peaks belonging to the chemically adsorbed oxygen is remarkably enhanced, among which the enhancement for the peak at 378 ℃ is the most significant. By integrating the curves, the desorption amount of chemically adsorbed oxygen could be calculated, as listed in Table 3. Pt/CeO2 possesses a higher amount of O2 − (ad) and O− (ad), indicating the presence of more surface oxygen vacancies [41]. This result is in good agreement with those of XPS and Raman. 3.2.3 Evolution of active oxygen species In the case of CeO2-based catalysts, surface coordinatively unsaturated metal cations and oxygen anion vacancies could participate in the activation of reactants [45]. Specifically, adsorbed O3 might result in the formation of superoxide (O2 -) and/or peroxide (O2 2-) species on defect sites, which are postulated to be kinetically important intermediates during the O3 decomposition process [37]. Of particular note is that atomic oxygen is also an intermediate, which, however, is in transient state and eventually transforms to the above oxygen species [46]. To investigate the intrinsic relationship between the O3 decomposition performance and the catalytic ozonation activity, in-situ Raman was conducted to detect the O2 - and O2 2- generated from O3 decomposition in the presence or absence of toluene. In return, the response of O2 - and O2 2- can be used to verify the amount of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface [45]. The curves marked with “initial” in Fig. 11(a) and (b) represent the Raman spectra for catalysts after pretreatment. In the range of 700–1400 cm-1, both catalysts possess three peaks at 1179, 1050 and 833 cm-1, belonging to the second-order longitudinal optical mode (2LO) of ceria, trace nitrate or phosphate species in ceria, and O2 2- adsorbed on defect sites, respectively [47]. After introduction of O2, the intensity of the peak at 833 cm-1 is significantly increased and a weak shoulder peak appears at 860 cm-1 in the spectra marked with “O 2 ” for both samples. Subsequently, O2 was replaced by O3. In the spectra marked with “O 3 ”, the intensity of the peaks at 833 and 860 cm-1 are further increased, and a new shoulder peak comes out at 1139 cm-1 for both catalysts. Notably, a new shoulder peak at 890 cm-1 is particularly observed in the Pt/CeO2. Based on the previous studies, the peaks at 833, 860 and 890 cm-1 are assigned to the O2 2- adsorbed on defect sites with different aggregation states [48]. Whereas, the peak at 1139 cm-1 is assigned to the adsorbed O2 -. To compare the amount of O2 2- generated in the O3 atmosphere, Raman spectra were deconvoluted through peak fitting. By using the peak area of 2LO mode (1179 cm-1) as the basis to normalize other peaks, the relative content of O2 2- could be obtained. As seen in Fig. 11(c), the relative contents of the three different O2 2- in Pt/CeO2 are 41.4%, 23.3%, and 17.1%, which are significantly higher than those in CeO2. These results highlight that more O2 2- can be formed on the Pt/CeO2 surface in the presence of O3. In-situ Raman spectroscopy in the presence of toluene is displayed in Fig. 12. In this experiment, the samples that were pretreated under O3 were firstly swept by N2 to remove the weakly adsorbed oxygen species (spectra marked with “N 2 ”). Notably, the peak corresponding to the O2 - at 1139 cm-1 disappears, and the intensity of the peaks ascribed to the O2 2- at 833, 860 and 890 cm-1 decreases in this step. This result demonstrates the higher stability of O2 2- on the catalyst surface. Afterward, toluene was introduced into the system (spectra marked with “Toluene”). Toluene adsorption peaks appear at 822, 1005, 1155 and 1290 cm-1, while the intensity of the peaks for the O2 2- at 860 and 890 cm-1 weakens. From this result, one could deduce that O2 2- was consumed during the toluene oxidation. Besides, the structure signal of CeO2 at 1179 cm-1 seems to disappear and be replaced by that of toluene at 1155 cm-1. This could be probably attributed to the more sensitive detection for the toluene signals in Raman spectroscopy. Similarly, Mao et al. [49] have confirmed that the O2 2- formed during O3 decomposition were pivotal reactive species for the catalytic ozonation of VOCs. Compared to CeO2, the Pt/CeO2 possesses a higher amount of oxygen vacancies that are beneficial for O3 adsorption and decomposition, and thus generation of more O2 2-. The presence of more O2 2- is proved to facilitate the toluene oxidation and the Pt/CeO2 exhibits enhanced catalytic activity as a consequence. 3.3 Proposed reaction pathways A general mechanism of O3 decomposition on catalyst surface has been established by Oyama et al. [50]: adsorbed O3 firstly dissociates to form an O2 and an atomic oxygen (O*), which subsequently reacts with another O3 to generate a gaseous O2 and an adsorbed oxygen (O2*); the final step involves the decomposition of the O2* to form a gaseous O2. In our study, in-situ Raman in the presence of toluene allows identifying the participation of O2 2- that is preliminarily formed during O3 decomposition for the catalytic ozonation of toluene. In light of the above results and discussion, plausible reaction pathways based on the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism for such kind of reaction on the Pt-CeO2/BEA surface are proposed as the following: (R1) O 3 + S O v + e → O 2 + O − (R2) O 3 + O − → O 2 + O 2 − (R3) O 2 − + e → O 2 2 − (R4) C 7 H 8 + S a → C 7 H 8 * (R5) C 7 H 8 * + ( O − + O 2 2 − … ) → by_products * → CO 2 + H 2 O where SOv is assigned to active sites such as oxygen vacancies and acid sides for O3 adsorption and decomposition, Sa represents active sites for toluene adsorption and activation. From Section 3.2.1, Pt/CeO2 hardly reacts with toluene in the absence of O3 below 110 ℃. In this case, the major role of Pt/CeO2 is to provide adsorption sites for the toluene. As described in Fig. 13, after introducing O3, the O3 molecule chemically adsorbs on the CeO2 surface by inserting an O atom into the oxygen vacancy site, which is an electron donor and transfers an electron to this O atom. A charged oxygen species (O-) is thus formed in this oxygen vacancy and an O2 molecule desorbs in the gas phase (R1). Then, another O3 molecule reacts with the abovementioned O- to generate a gaseous O2 molecule and an O2 - (R2), in which the latter could accept an electron to produce an O2 2- (R3). The formation of O2 - and O2 2- was confirmed by in-situ Raman in Section 3.2.3. Subsequently, the O2 2- participates in the oxidation of toluene, which preliminarily adsorbs on active sites of the catalyst surface (R4), to form oxygen-containing byproducts and finally the harmless CO2 and H2O (R5). Summarily, O3 decomposition is the key step that depends on the amount of oxygen vacancies and the O2 2- is an important participant in the catalytic ozonation of toluene. 4 Conclusions In this study, Pt-CeO2/BEA catalysts with a Pt loading amount lower in order of magnitude than those reported in the literature were prepared by the Pt NPs adsorption method and displayed encouraging catalytic performance toward catalytic ozonation of toluene. Pt/CeO2 and Pt/SiO2 also prepared by the same method were employed to elucidate the intrinsic reasons for the performance improvement. Based on the catalytic behaviors and structural characterization, several conclusions can be drawn: (1) the enhanced Pt-CeO2 SMSI in the Pt-CeO2/BEA-P is induced by the formation of much smaller, more uniform and dispersive Pt NPs through the adsorption method; (2) O3 decomposition process determines the generation of O2 2-, which is an important participant in the catalytic ozonation of toluene; (3) the anchoring effect for Pt NPs by the Pt-O-Ce bonds, the greater amount of oxygen vacancies and more generated O2 2- are potentially responsible for the performance improvement. What is more important, the presented catalysts with such a low loading amount of Pt NPs exhibit the facility of preparation, cost-efficiency and competitive catalytic activity, demonstrating the potential practical application for the simultaneous treatment of O3 and VOCs. coredata.dc:description: The supported catalyst of Pt-CeO2/BEA with low loading amount (0.07 wt%) of Pt nanoparticles presented competitive performance towards catalytic ozonation of toluene. Characterization results demonstrated that the improved activity could be attributed to the enhanced Pt-CeO2 strong metal-support interaction induced by the formation of much smaller, more uniform and dispersive Pt nanoparticles through the adsorption method. Furthermore, Pt/CeO2 and Pt/SiO2 were employed to elucidate the intrinsic reasons for the activity improvement. Various techniques such as XPS, Raman, O2-TPD, etc. were performed to characterize the physicochemical properties. Results showed that the anchoring effect for Pt nanoparticles by the Pt-O-Ce bonds, greater amount of oxygen vacancies and more generated peroxide species are potentially responsible for the improvement of catalytic performance. In-situ Raman confirmed the participation of peroxide species in toluene oxidation, which were previously formed during the ozone decomposition. Plausible reaction pathways for the involving reactions on catalyst surface were also proposed.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced performance of low Pt loading amount on Pt-CeO2 catalysts prepared by adsorption method for catalytic ozonation of toluene
